case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax, Madhya Pradesh and Bhopal v. Vyas Dotiwala

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 222 of 1956 filed by special leave.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 222 of 1956. Appeal by special leave

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and decree dated December 8, 1953 of Nagpur High Court in Misc. Civil Case No. 55 of 1950.

anchor.surface_text: from the judgment and decree dated December 8, 1953, of the former Nagpur High Court in Misc. Civil Case No. 55 of 1950.

facts.text: Appellant is Commissioner of Income-tax, Madhya Pradesh and Bhopal.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal is by the Commissioner of Income-tax, Madhya Pradesh and Bhopal.

facts.text: Respondents are assessees Vyas Dotiwala.

anchor.surface_text: The respondents are the assessees Vyas Dotiwala.

facts.text: Assessment years concerned are 1945-46 and 1946-47.

anchor.surface_text: we wish to state that the assessment years concerned were 1945-46 and 1946-47.

facts.text: In or about July 1943, considerable difficulty felt about cloth, Deputy Commissioner Amraoti evolved a scheme.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that in or about July 1943 when considerable difficulty was being felt about cloth, the Deputy Commissioner, Amraoti, evolved a scheme to solve that difficulty.

facts.text: Kisanlal Vyas and firm Edulji Framji Dotiwala undertook to finance the scheme without charging interest or profit, appointed as financiers and distributors of standard cloth for Amraoti town, camp and interior areas.

anchor.surface_text: Under that scheme Kisanlal Vyas and a firm called Edulji Framji Dotiwala who have in these proceedings been referred to as Dotiwala, undertook to finance the scheme without charging any interest or profit and were appointed as financiers and also distributors of a variety of cloth called standard cloth for the town and camp of Amraoti and certain areas in the interior

facts.text: Vyas and Dotiwala as association of persons are the assessees.

anchor.surface_text: Vyas and Dotiwala, who as an association of persons are the assessees concerned,

facts.text: Assessees agreed to open account in Imperial Bank of India to finance purchases of cloth.

anchor.surface_text: agreed to open an account in the Imperial Bank of India to be operated by them out of which the purchases of the cloth were to be financed.

facts.text: On arrival of consignment, assessees to pay Deputy Commissioner value of consignment plus 6-1/4% of ex-mill price.

anchor.surface_text: on the arrival of a consignment of cloth, the assessees were to pay to the Deputy Commissioner, Amraoti, the value of the consignment together with 6-1/4 per cent. of the ex-mill price.

facts.text: Deputy Commissioner pays 4-1/2% of ex-mill price to assessees for contingent expenses, not to exceed 3%.

anchor.surface_text: The Deputy Commissioner would pay 4-1/2 per cent. of the ex-mill price to the assessees out of the amount paid by the latter as aforesaid for contingent expenses of working the scheme. The scheme provided that the contingent expenses were not to exceed 3 percent. of the ex-mill price.

facts.text: Cloth distributed by assessees through shop in Amraoti town and camp, and through Tehsildars with Patils in interiors.

anchor.surface_text: The cloth coming to the hands of the assessees was to be distributed in Amraoti town and camp through a shop to be opened by the assessees and in the interiors of the area concerned through Tehsildars with Patils under them.

facts.text: Distribution under control of Deputy Commissioner, who is responsible to assessees for sale proceeds from Tehsildars.

anchor.surface_text: The substance of the arrangement of distribution appears to have been that it would be entirely under the control of the Deputy Commissioner who made himself responsible to the assessees for the sale proceeds receivable from the Tehsildars.

facts.text: Deputy Commissioner decides price for cloth to consumers and entitled buyers.

anchor.surface_text: The Deputy Commissioner was to decide the price for which the cloth was to be sold to the consumers and also the persons entitled to buy the cloth.

facts.text: Out of sale proceeds, Deputy Commissioner pays assessees the advances made for cloth.

anchor.surface_text: Out of the sale proceeds the Deputy Commissioner was to pay to the assessees whatever they had advanced on account of the cloth.

facts.text: Para 14 of scheme: Profits resulting from scheme to be utilised for charitable purposes decided by Deputy Commissioner in consultation with advisory committee.

anchor.surface_text: The most important provision in this scheme is para. 14 which is set out below. Profits resulting from the scheme shall be utilised for such charitable purposes as may be decided on by the Deputy Commissioner in consultation with the advisory committee appointed to supervise the scheme.

facts.text: Books of assessees showed Rs. 34,737 for 1945-46 and Rs. 17,682 for 1946-47 as profits from scheme.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that the books of the assessees showed Rs. 34,737/- for the assessment year 1945-46 and Rs. 17,682/- for the assessment year 1946-47 as profits earned in working the scheme.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer assessed assessees to tax on the profits.

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Officer assessed the assessees to tax on the profits so earned.

facts.text: Assessees contended before ITO that income exempt under s. 4(3)(i-a) of Indian Income-tax Act, 1922.

anchor.surface_text: The assessment orders made by this officer would appear to show that the only point urged by the assessees before him against the assessment was that the income was exempt from taxation under s. 4(3)(i-a) of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922.

facts.text: Assessees appealed to Appellate Assistant Commissioner, contention repeated, order confirmed.

anchor.surface_text: The assessees went up in appeal to the Appellate Assistant Commissioner, before whom the same contention appears to have been repeated. The Appellate Commissioner confirmed the order of the Income-tax Officer.

facts.text: Assessees appealed to Appellate Tribunal.

anchor.surface_text: The assessees then appealed to the Appellate Tribunal.

facts.text: Tribunal held assessees objected on two grounds: income not theirs and exempt u/s 4(3)(i-a), per letter dated January 22, 1947.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal held-that the assessees had objected to the assessment before the Income-tax Officer on two grounds, namely, that the income was not the income of the assessees and that the income was exempt from taxation under s. 4(3)(i-a), as appeared from their letter dated January 22, 1947.

facts.text: Tribunal held profits not income of assessees, set aside assessment orders.

anchor.surface_text: The Appellate Tribunal agreed with the contention of the assessees that they were not liable to be taxed on the profits because these did not form their income. ... In this view of the matter the Tribunal set aside the orders of assessment.

facts.text: On revenue application, Tribunal referred question to High Court under s. 66(1).

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter, on the application of the revenue authorities the Tribunal referred the following question to the High Court under s. 66(1) of the Act

facts.text: Reference question: Whether income accrued to Vyas and Dotiwala from scheme and assessable in their hands.

anchor.surface_text: Whether on the facts of this case any income accrued to Messrs. Vyas and Dotiwala as the result of their associating themselves as financiers in the scheme for the distribution of standard cloth and, if so whether such income was assessable in their hands.

facts.text: High Court answered question in negative.

anchor.surface_text: In this view of the matter the High Court answered the question framed, in the negative.

facts.text: Supreme Court judgment delivered on October 3, 1958 by SARKAR J.

anchor.surface_text: 1958. October 3. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by SARKAR J.-

facts.text: It is not disputed that assessees worked the scheme and it produced profits as in assessment orders.

anchor.surface_text: It is not disputed that the assessees worked the scheme and such working produced the profits as found in the assessment orders.
Appeal by special leave from the judgment
This is an appeal brought by special leave
under s. 66 1  of the Income-tax Act.

issues.text: Whether on the facts of this case any income accrued to Messrs. Vyas and Dotiwala as the result of their associating themselves as financiers in the scheme for the distribution of standard cloth and, if so whether such income was assessable in their hands.

issues.text: Whether the income was exempt from taxation under s. 4(3)(i-a) of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922

anchor.surface_text: s. 4 3  i-a , as appeared from their letter dated January 22, 1947. One of these alone had been dealt with by that officer, as appears from his order earlier referred to.

arguments.claim: the income was exempt from taxation under s. 4(3)(i-a) of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922

anchor.surface_text: s. 4 3  i-a  of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922. The officer rejected this companytention. The assessees went up in appeal to the Appellate Assistant Commissioner,

arguments.court_reasoning: Section 4(3)(i-a) applies to income from business carried on behalf of a religious or charitable institution; the scheme was not carried on on behalf of any such institution

arguments.claim: the income was not the income of the assessees

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal held-that the assessees had objected to the assessment before the Income-tax Officer on two grounds, namely, that the income was Dot the income of the assessees and that the income was exempt from taxation under s. 4 3  i-a ,

arguments.court_reasoning: Profits accrued to assessees as they carried on the business despite Deputy Commissioner's control

arguments.claim: assessees were merely the financiers and also managers under the Deputy Commissioner to carry out the scheme and profits did not form their income

anchor.surface_text: The Appellate Tribunal agreed with the companyten- tion of the assessees that they were number liable to be taxed on the profits because these did number form their income. ... The Tribunal was of the view that the scheme was companypletely under the companytrol

arguments.court_reasoning: Control by Deputy Commissioner does not prevent assessees from carrying on business; they agreed to do business in a certain manner

arguments.claim: under s. 4 it was necessary to prove that the assessees received or should be deemed to have received income; assessees had not actually received any such income and no deeming provision applied

anchor.surface_text: On that reference the High Court held that under the charging section in the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922, namely, s. 4, it was necessary for the revenue authorities to prove that the assessees received or should be deemed to have received income or profit from the scheme during the relevant period.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: matter the High Court answered the question framed, in the negative. The learned Solicitor-General companytends that the High Court failed to apprecia

arguments.court_reasoning: High Court failed to appreciate real question of accrual of income, not receipt; profits formed income of assessees

arguments.claim: High Court failed to appreciate the real question which was whether income had accrued, not whether received or deemed received; profits formed the income of the assessees

anchor.surface_text: The learned Solicitor-General companytends that the High Court failed to appreciate the real question. He says that the question was number whether income was received or deemed to be received but whether income had accrued and the point for decision was,

court_response_anchor.surface_text: matter the High Court answered the question framed, in the negative. The learned Solicitor-General companytends that the High Court failed to apprecia

arguments.court_reasoning: We agree with this criticism of the judgment of the High Court

arguments.claim: control of the Deputy Commissioner cannot prevent the working of the scheme by the assessees from being a business carried on by them

anchor.surface_text: It is number disputed that the assessees worked the scheme and such working produced the profits as found in the assessment orders. The Tribunal thought that since the scheme was companypletely under the companytrol of the Deputy Commissioner,

arguments.claim: assessees had agreed to do business in a certain manner; Deputy Commissioner's guarantee indicates assessees were treated as owners of the business

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to see that the fact of the companytrol of the Deputy Commissioner can prevent the working of the scheme by the assessees from being a business carried on by them. In our view, it only companyes to this that the assessees had agreed to do business

arguments.claim: claim for exemption under s. 4(3)(i-a) would not arise unless assessees were carrying on business

anchor.surface_text: Again the claim, may be in the alternative, by the assessees for exemption under s. 4 3  i- a  would number arise unless the assessees were carrying on a business.

arguments.claim: para 14 contemplates profits resulting from the scheme belonging to assessees; provision to devote to charity indicates profits would otherwise be utilisable by assessees

anchor.surface_text: Lastly, para. 14 of the scheme which we, have earlier set out, clearly companytemplates profits resulting from the scheme. The provision that the profits would be devoted to charity to be decided by the Deputy Commissioner, would indicate that without it the profits would have been utilisable by the assessees.

arguments.claim: if profits were of Government, no necessity for para 14; working produced profits belonging to assessees

anchor.surface_text: The profits belonged to the assessees and hence the necessity for this agreement so that the assessees might be made to spend them on charity. If, as the Tribunal thought, the profits were of the Government, there was numbernecessity for the Government providing for the profits being expended on charity,

arguments.claim: agreement to devote profits to charity does not change their character or make them cease to be assessees' income

anchor.surface_text: The fact remains that the working of the scheme produced profits and apart from para. 14 such profits undoubtedly belonged to the assessees. If they chose to agree by para. 14 to devote the profits to charity, that was their business the profits made by them would number change their character

arguments.claim: assessees liable to tax on profits actually made whether they agreed not to make profits or not

anchor.surface_text: We might also say that there is numberhing in the scheme which shows that the assessees had undertaken number to make any profits on the distribution work under the scheme they had only agreed to finance the scheme without receiving any interest or profit. Furthermore, since the assessees actually made the profits,

arguments.claim: scheme considered as business was not carried on on behalf of any religious or charitable institution
profits were the income which accrued to the assessees and assessable; not exempt under s. 4(3)(i-a)

anchor.surface_text: In the result, we would answer both parts of the question framed, in-the affirmative. We hold that the profits were the income which accrued to the assessees and such income is assessable to income-tax and is number exempt from taxation under s. 4 3  i-a .

holdings.text: The profits were the income which accrued to the assessees and such income is assessable to income-tax
holdings.reasoning_summary: Assessees worked the scheme producing profits; control by Deputy Commissioner does not negate their business activity; para 14 contemplates profits as theirs, to be devoted to charity; actual making of profits triggers tax liability regardless of agreement

holdings.text: The income is not exempt from taxation under s. 4(3)(i-a)
holdings.reasoning_summary: Scheme not carried on behalf of any religious or charitable institution; exemption requires business on behalf of such institution with income applied solely thereto

holdings.text: The fact of the control of the Deputy Commissioner cannot prevent the working of the scheme by the assessees from being a business carried on by them

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to see that the fact of the control of the Deputy Commissioner can prevent the working of the scheme by the assessees from being a business carried on by them. In our view, it only comes to this that the assessees had agreed to do business

holdings.reasoning_summary: Assessees agreed to finance and distribute under scheme terms; guarantee by DC treats them as owners; alternative exemption claim implies business activity

holdings.text: Para 14 of the scheme contemplates that profits resulting from the scheme belonged to the assessees

anchor.surface_text: Lastly, para. 14 of the scheme which we, have earlier set out, clearly contemplates profits resulting from the scheme. The provision that the profits would be devoted to charity to be decided by the Deputy Commissioner, would indicate that without it the profits

holdings.reasoning_summary: Provision to utilise profits for charity implies they would otherwise be utilisable by assessees; no need for such clause if profits were Government's

holdings.text: Agreement by para 14 to devote profits to charity does not change their character or make them cease to be the assessees' income

anchor.surface_text: The fact remains that the working of the scheme produced profits and apart from para. 14 such profits undoubtedly belonged to the assessees. If they chose to agree by para. 14 to devote the profits to charity, that was their business the profits made by them

holdings.reasoning_summary: Profits accrue upon production from business; subsequent disposition does not alter accrual or character as income

holdings.text: Assessees are liable to tax on profits actually made whether they agreed not to make profits or not

anchor.surface_text: We might also say that there is nothing in the scheme which shows that the assessees had undertaken not to make any profits on the distribution work under the scheme they had only agreed to finance the scheme without receiving any interest or profit.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Actual realisation of profits from scheme operation triggers tax; prior agreement disclaiming profit does not exempt if profits arise

holdings.text: Section 4(3)(i-a) applies to income derived from business carried on on behalf of a religious or charitable institution when applied solely thereto; scheme was not so carried on
holdings.reasoning_summary: No religious or charitable institution involved; assessees conducted scheme independently despite govt oversight

holdings.text: The High Court failed to appreciate the real question of whether income had accrued, focusing instead on receipt or deemed receipt

anchor.surface_text: The learned Solicitor-General contends that the High Court failed to appreciate the real question. He says that the question was not whether income was received or deemed to be received but whether income had accrued and the point for decision was,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Charging section s.4 concerns accrual forming total income, not mere receipt; agrees with Solicitor-General's criticism

anchor.surface_text: In the result, we would answer both parts of the question framed, in-the affirmative. We hold that the profits were the income which accrued to the assessees and such income is assessable to income-tax and is number exempt from taxation under s. 4 3

outcome.relief_summary: The question is answered in the affirmative; profits constituted income of the assessees liable to income-tax and not exempt under section 4(3)(i-a)
